case_vignette: A 74-year-old man with a history of type II diabetes and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden-onset, painless vision loss in his left eye. He describes the feeling as if things went black in his left eye suddenly. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves III-XII as intact. The patient is unable to see out of his left eye but has normal vision in his right eye. The rest of his exam including strength, sensation, and gait are unremarkable. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A and an ultrasound of the eye is performed as seen in Figure B. Fundoscopy is performed as seen in Figure C. A CT scan of the head is currently pending.

Great, thank you for providing that information. Based on what you've told me, I would like to consider a few possible causes of your sudden vision loss:

1. Central retinal vein occlusion: This is a blockage of the central retinal vein, which can cause sudden vision loss in one eye. It is often associated with age, hypertension, and diabetes.
2. Branch retinal vein occlusion: This is a blockage of a smaller retinal vein, which can also cause sudden vision loss in one eye. It is similar to central retinal vein occlusion, but is less common.
3. Retinal detachment: This is a condition where the retina becomes detached from the back of the eye, causing vision loss. It can be caused by injury, disease, or age-related changes.
4. Optic neuritis: This is inflammation of the optic nerve, which can cause sudden vision loss in one eye. It is often associated with viral infections, such as multiple sclerosis, and can also be caused by other underlying conditions.
